You're not wrong but it really should be pointed out that Washington VERY aware and VERY concerned about his men's suffering in Valley Forge and the entire war, really. His hands were completely tied, though. Congress and the States selfishly refused to provide supplies and aid for the troops dying for the nation's independence. Washington has to eat, he's the commander, and if the commander is starved to death, the army collapses. He's primarily the reason why the army held together through that winter. Washington's legacy as an amazing leader and general is BECAUSE of his incredible loyalty to his men, BECAUSE he fought fiercely to improve the situation for them while the legislature at the time ignored their suffering. So to just casually throw out that line, to suggest that Washington was fat and happy in his tent while his troops starved to death, is not only inaccurate but it is flagrantly ignoring the most significant point about the winter in Valley Forge.

No US conflict is more passively, acceptably romanticized as the Independence War. In truth in many places it took on the atmosphere of a Civil War. No state was more war-torn and violent than New Jersey during this period. In two square miles from where I sit typing this there are - to my knowledge - at least two, dusty - ill-kept plaques devoted to Patriot militias that were executed, bayoneted in their sleep, put up against the precipice of a ditch and shot, etc not by the 'redcoats' but by their Loyalist neighbors. In fact, the last shots fired in anger of this war were in recompense for the brutality of militias on both sides, as they engaged in fighting even after the peace treaty had been signed. Pine Bandits hid out in the Barrens, villages were torched by one force or the other - and that's just the Southern part of the State. The North was characterized by oscillating front lines and what's called the "Forage War" where both sides sent out small detachments to pillage supplies from the land. So neglected are the small sins of this conflict, all in the name of our National Creation Myth - and it does a disservice to history. Not even New Jersey historians care to remember the conflict that gave birth to such a ravaged landscape, that cemented the ill-reputation of New Jersey very early among the colonies in much the same way people thought of the ex-Yugoslav countries in the 90's. That led to the genesis of urban legends and wive's tails and permanently painted the Pine Barrens as a dark and sinister place.

New Jersey's history is an especially dark one, and it's still a meme for people like John Greene all of these decades later.

I disagree with John's interpretation of the Mystery Document. I would argue that it's not communist, but rather the precise opposite, arguing that the institution of private property (whose treatment under law is equal, i.e. your property rights are just as secure as those of powerful families) is what protects a society against tyranny and ensures that liberty does not expire.

This interpretation looks odd to us, but that's because the equality of property rights is a lot more obvious to inhabitants of modern classically-liberal societies than it was back in the late 18th Century, when remnants of the feudal system (particularly in Continental Europe, the best-known examples mostly being from France) meant that often the property rights of the smallholding peasant weren't every bit as sacrosanct under the law as the rights of a great lord.

It is, thus, when the "combinations of powerful families" can, in the manner of some mediæval warlord, expropriate the individual, that the people will lose their power, and liberty expire.

Who won? The English Parliament -- no, not the British Parliament. Throughout the 17th century, civil war and revolution in England had enshrined the supremacy of Parliament over the Sovereign. The matter was definitively resolved in the constitution of 1689, when rudimentary notions of equality of rights and of parliamentary representation became supreme. And then, came that thing called Great Britain.

So when all those really-important would-be aristocrats and businessmen in the colonies saw that both Parliament and the King were rejecting their right to have a voice in the economic issues that were the backbone of their wealth, they were echoing the constitution that pre-dated the UK. But they did get the attention of the French, who were still, as always, really interested in new ideas, and in smashing up England. Not only did they absorb all that hypocritical American rhetoric about rights and democracy -- something even the Americans took with a grain of salt -- they implemented it in the French Revolution which worked its way through Germany and France in the 19th century, culminating in the toppling of almost all monarchies by World War I.

I know I'm like 3 1/2 years late watching this and commenting, but I think it's extraordinarily naive to state that America no longer leads in equality of opportunity.  It is excruciatingly difficult to make international comparisons of economic mobility in a scientific fashion.  The biggest issue is to account for differences in absolute income and income redistribution.  Studies often show that Scandinavian countries demonstrate greater economic mobility, but this advantage disappears when accounting for higher governmental redistribution (ie, if the government redistributes more income, inter-generational income differences don't have to be as large to change quintile; this proves the country is better at giving poor people money not opportunity).
America absolutely still leads in equality of opportunity. To say otherwise is liberal hogwash.

Bernardo de Gálvez ( From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia )

In recognition of his work and help to the American cause, George Washington took him to his right in the parade of July 4 and the American Congress recognized Gálvez for his aid during the Revolution.

On December 16, 2014, the United States Congress conferred honorary citizenship on Gálvez, citing him as a "hero of the Revolutionary War who risked his life for the freedom of the United States people and provided supplies, intelligence, and strong military support to the war effort."[1]

In Baton Rouge, Louisiana, (present-day state capital), Galvez Plaza is laid out next to City Hall and used frequently as a site for municipal events. Also, the 13-story Galvez Building is part of the state government's administrative office-building complex in the Capitol Park section of downtown Baton Rouge.

All i know is At about 5 a.m., 700 British troops, on a mission to capture Patriot leaders and seize a Patriot arsenal, march into Lexington to find 77 armed minutemen under Captain John Parker waiting for them on the town’s common green. British Major John Pitcairn ordered the outnumbered Patriots to disperse, and after a moment’s hesitation the Americans began to drift off the green. Suddenly, the “shot heard around the world” was fired from an undetermined gun, and a cloud of musket smoke soon covered the green. When the brief Battle of Lexington ended, eight Americans lay dead or dying and 10 others were wounded. Only one British soldier was injured, but the American Revolution had begun.

By 1775, tensions between the American colonies and the British government approached the breaking point, especially in Massachusetts, where Patriot leaders formed a shadow revolutionary government and trained militias to prepare for armed conflict with the British troops occupying Boston. In the spring of 1775, General Thomas Gage, the British governor of Massachusetts, received instructions from England to seize all stores of weapons and gunpowder accessible to the American insurgents. On April 18, he ordered British troops to march against the Patriot arsenal at Concord and capture Patriot leaders Samuel Adams and John Hancock, known to be hiding at Lexington.

The Boston Patriots had been preparing for such a military action by the British for some time, and upon learning of the British plan, Patriots Paul Revere and William Dawes were ordered to set out to rouse the militiamen and warn Adams and Hancock. When the British troops arrived at Lexington, Adams, Hancock, and Revere had already fled to Philadelphia, and a group of militiamen were waiting. The Patriots were routed within minutes, but warfare had begun, leading to calls to arms across the Massachusetts countryside.

When the British troops reached Concord at about 7 a.m., they found themselves encircled by hundreds of armed Patriots. They managed to destroy the military supplies the Americans had collected but were soon advanced against by a gang of minutemen, who inflicted numerous casualties. Lieutenant Colonel Frances Smith, the overall commander of the British force, ordered his men to return to Boston without directly engaging the Americans. As the British retraced their 16-mile journey, their lines were constantly beset by Patriot marksmen firing at them Indian-style from behind trees, rocks, and stone walls. At Lexington, Captain Parker’s militia had its revenge, killing several British soldiers as the Red Coats hastily marched through his town. By the time the British finally reached the safety of Boston, nearly 300 British soldiers had been killed, wounded, or were missing in action. The Patriots suffered fewer than 100 casualties.

The battles of Lexington and Concord were the first battles of the American Revolution, a conflict that would escalate from a colonial uprising into a world war that, seven years later, would give birth to the independent United States of America.

2:41 In all honesty, Cornwallis' decision to establish a fortified base at Yorktown wasn't stupid at the time he made it. Entrenching yourself on a peninsula is a problem if you don't control the sea, but it's great if you do...and the British had throughout the entire war up to that time, and had little reason to fear they would lose that control. Plus, the primary source of supply for the British was seaborne (as noted, their forays inland into the countryside tended to not go well), so it made perfect sense for them to establish a fortified base at a port. The British had a longstanding tradition of sea supremacy, and tended to base their campaign plans around that. The British maintained sea supremacy throughout almost the entire war...except for that one brief period where they didn't, which turned out to be the important part. Just discovered Crash Course and have LOVED it!  This is very well presented and entertaining.  However, having binge-watched a few of these over the past few days, I'm very surprised at the disparity between the presentation of the Crusades and the American Revolution.  John was far more charitable towards the Crusaders - which was surprising because no one is, ever (he's the exception!!!) - than our Founding Fathers.  John made a point to keep us from judging the Crusaders too harshly through the lens of modernity as it was a different time and place; they genuinely believed in what they did despite more than a few "bad apples" - to put it mildly.  But then the American Revolution gets a full blown modern judgement.

Many of the Founding Fathers were well aware of the hypocrisy between advocating for the rights of all men and possessing slaves but they were also pragmatic and knew they couldn't both defeat Britain (with little support from colonists already) and completely overthrowing the social order; first things first.  Revolutions that attempt to change everything at once often end up changing nothing.  Overemphasis on Jefferson is an example of slight bias.  Yes, he's the author of the Declaration but he didn't do it in a vacuum, it was a process and I think a better source for the "soul" of the Revolution was John Adams, who wrote extensively about the process in his correspondence to Abigail.  He was also a bit ornery, so he would probably remain forgotten if it were not for David McCollough/HBO...but I digress.

Furthermore, if we read Adams, what made the American Revolution truly "revolutionary" is that it was the first time - ever - that a nation was founded on an anthropology.  Man didn't have to appeal to a King for his rights nor did he have to appeal to other men (which is why we're a Republic and not a Democracy because a tyranny of the majority is still tyranny) but to the very author of our existence: God.  That is why the heavily "borrowed" work of Locke's differed in one major regard: "property" is quantitative but "happiness" is qualitative. And they did not think of "happiness" in modern terms (affectations of pleasure or contentment) but, rather, in Classical terms from philosophers like Aristotle.  Happiness is the fulfillment of a life lived in virtue.  And THAT is what made the Revolution different.  They believe that only a moral people can be free because only virtue preserves true liberty.  If a man cannot control himself, he will be controlled by others (such as corporations that fuel consumerism or the Government itself).  A populace lacking control of its passions will have their passions manipulated because if history has taught us anything, it's that no one has ever stopped wanting control.

That is why religious institutions could not be - and should not be - promoted by the Government but individuals being religious WAS promoted (see Washington's farewell address).  Heck, that's why Thanksgiving was established at all as a national holiday!  To give thanks to our Creator for our blessings.  Without God, who are we "thanking?"  The Government?  Ourselves?  Seems a bit pretentious...

To the Founding Fathers' credit, while they might not have achieved everything modernity wants in one fell swoop over 200 years ago, they provided the foundation for one of the most diverse nations in the world with a greater presence of diversity in leadership than any other nation in the world.  Could it be better?  Of course, everything can be.  But some great strides have been made over the past 200 years which ultimately owe their inspiration to what they did and gave their lives for.

Okay, off soap box....keep up the good work!

In reality, "Life, Liberty, and the Pursuit of Happiness" aren't inalienable rights. "Inalienable" means "unable to be taken away from or given away by the possessor." Liberty was obviously taken away from slaves and females, but even if you ignore that "tiny" oversight, the soldiers in the revolutionary war were trying to BUY liberty with their lives- and thankfully they succeeded. As for life, what right to life does a human have, drowning in the pacific? "The ocean will not heed his cries." (Starship troopers). (If he ever HAD a right to live, WATER just took it from him. Inalienable, indeed.) If 2 men are trapped, and in order to survive, cannibalism is the only option, whose right is inalienable? (If you ask one of them, they will probably say, "MINE!") As for PURSUIT of happiness, it actually IS inalienable, but it is not a right: it is a state of being; and no King, Emperor, Governor, or President can TRULY give you happiness itself.

Although Jefferson's personal actions contradict much of his rhetoric, I do not believe its fair to make a direct comparison between him an George Washington. The British government had clear limits -- in fact, one of the main reasons for the rebellion was that the colonial leadership felt like England had not been respecting the traditional forms and limits of governance it had itself set precedent for.  The American rebellion was about many things, but "limited versus unlimited government" was certainly not one of them.

The British lost the war partly because of the difficulty of supply chain maintenance, yes. England at the time was the most powerful military and economic force in the world, but it had weaknesses -- weaknesses rebel leaders exploited to win the war.

Absolutely.  Lincoln and the North were not abolitionists and did not go to war in 1861 with the intention of destroying the institution of slavery. And Lincoln did indeed intend to keep slavery from spreading any further, which deeply angered many Southern elites.

Canada at the time was basically two colonies, Nova Scotia and Quebec.  Quebec didn't rebel because life under British rule was SO MUCH BETTER than Ancien Regime France (a controversial statement but I stand by it) especially when Westminster passed the Quebec Act (one of the Intolerable Acts).
Nova Scotia didn't rebel for the same reason Georgia almost didn't.  Georgia was really small and really dependent on British governance.  Nova Scotia was basically just a military post in Halifax.

Canada did rebel, 1837-1838, it didn't go well.  There was a massive riot in Montreal in 1848 or 1849 (I can't remember which year, which is awful because it was such an important event) in which the people demanded to be annexed by USA.  The rebellions were never successful because, yes, we thought of ourselves as Britons, but also because we were pretty well-governed, and on the whole when we were ready for autonomy, as much was given to us as we could handle in a slow evolution of sovereignty

Strawman in debate and logic is defined as taking your opponent's argument, changing it, mistating it or over simplifying it, then arguing against the changed argument rather than the original.

In Locke's day one had property in one's body, property in one's speech, property in one's estate. Today property mainly refers to the estate part. So when Locke advocated property rights he was referring to self ownership as well, ie. liberty.

I think the point that John is trying to hammer through is that it isn't the flags or the guns or the barricades that truly change history.  It's the ideas that drive those acts of defiance.  In that way, revolutions as we traditionally view them, with start and end dates, leading figures, and political outcomes, don't tend to change much.  But the ideas and experiments that they include do.  The Concert of Europe could take away parliaments and liberties, but the ideas were there to stay.

But Bleeding Kansas was technically *before* the Civil War and is even often called "The Tragic Prelude". It's important to remember he's not actually to the Civil War part yet. He was just making a reference to it. At this point the US doesn't exist that far west.

It's a hard thing to quantify, but one way to look at it is through economic mobility, the ease with which people can move between economic brackets, like what % of kids born in the bottom 5th ever move into a higher bracket. In a nation like Denmark it's ~80%, in the USA it's ~58%. (see Joseph Stiglitz's "The Price of Inequality"). You could also consider barriers like gender and religion. You might look at political leaders for example, USA has never had a non-christian or women President.

I think the real versus incorporeal property distinction is what Kim is referring to. Traditionally the only property that mattered for things like freedom (and other things) was real property/estate. Other property, or chattels, wasn't considered to be of much worth. (if destroyed or stolen, the legal remedy was money, not return of the chattel itself. With real property/estate the legal remedy was return of the property itself). These days the distinctions have become significantly blurred.

I don't think we're talking mass enfranchisement -- usually, from my reading of some historical documents, it was local or regional statutes that allowed, say, a widow to vote on her husband's behalf after his death, or any property owner to vote (with no requirement that s/he be a particular gender/ethnicity). Western states were a little more laissez-faire with the ol' franchise, though, so there were black voters north of the Mason-Dixon prior to the 15th amendment and female voters pre 15th.
